aberrant: straying from the right or normal way
absolve: to set free from an obligation
abstemious: restraint especially in the consumption of food or alcohol
abstinence: voluntary forbearance esp.  from indulgence of an appetite
abyss: an immeasurably deep gulf or great space
acerbic: acid in temper, mood or tone
acrimony: bitterness or sharpness of manner, speech, temper
adjunct: attached to another in a dependent or subordinate position
adulterate: to make impure by adding improper, or inferior ingredients
aesthete: a person who has refined sensitivity towards art or nature
allegiance: loyalty to a person, group, or cause
alleviate: to make easier to endure, lessen
ameliorate: to make or become better, to improve
amphibious: able to live in water and on land
anagram: a word/phrase formed from another rearranging its letters
analogy: similarity between like features of two things
anarchy: a state of society without government or law
anecdote: a short account of a history, usually amusing
anomalous: deviating from what is standard, expected or normal
anthology: a book or collection of writings
antidote: a remedy to counteract the effects of poison
antigen: a toxin that induces an immune response in the body
antipathy: a deep seated feeling of dislike
apostate: a person who forsakes his religion, cause, party
appraise: to assess the value or quality of
apprentice: a person who's learning a trade from a skilled employer
arouse: to evoke or awaken a feeling, emotion or response
articulate: express (an idea of feeling) fluently and coherently
artisan: a worker in a skilled trade
assail: to make a concerted of violent attach on
assert: to state a fact or belief confidently and forcefully
assimilate: to take in and incorporate as one's own
assuage: make an unpleasant feeling less intense
atrocity: an extremely wicked or cruel act
auditor: a person appointed to examine accounting records
austere: severe or strict in manner, attitude, or appearance
aver: to state or assert to be the case
banal: so lacking in originality as to be obvious and boring
bask: to revel in, to lie exposed to warmth and light
baste: to sew with long, loose stitches
bellicose: demonstrating aggression and willingness to fight
bequeath: to pass or to leave something over to someone else
bewilder: to cause someone to become perplexed and confused
bilge: the widest circumference or belly of a cask
blithe: showing a casual indifference which is callous or improper
boon: a thing that is helpful or beneficial
bourgeois: a member of the middle class
bovine: of, relating to, or affecting cattle
breach: an act of breaking a law, agreement or code of conduct
brevity: concise and exact use of words in writing or speech
burgeon: begin to grow or increase rapidly
buttress: to provide a structure with projecting supports
cacophony: a harsh, discordant mixture of sounds
cadet: a student in training at a military school
cadge: ask for or obtain something to which one is not entitled
calamity: an event causing great and often sudden damage or distress
calumniate: to make false and defamatory statements
capacious: having a lot of space inside, roomy
caprice: a sudden and unaccountable change of mood or behavior
capricious: given to sudden, unaccountable changes of mood or behavior
cartographer: the study and practice of making maps
catalyst: a person or thing that precipitates an event
catapult: a device that launches an object some distance
caustic: capable of destroying or eating away by chemical action
cavil: to make petty or unnecessary objections
cerebral: intellectual rather than emotional or physical
charlatan: a person falsely claiming to have special knowledge or skill
circuitous: roundabout, longer than the most direct way
circumspect: wary and unwilling to take risks
clairvoyant: having the power to see beyond the natural range of vision
coalesce: to grow together or into one body
coddle: to treat in an indulgent or overprotective way
codicil: a document that amends a previously executed will
colloquial: ordinary or familiar language rather than formal language
collusion: a secret agreement, especially for treacherous purposes
compatible: able to co-exist or occur together without conflict
compendium: a collection of concise but detailed info about one subject
competent: having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill
complacent: smug or uncritical satisfaction with one's achievements
compliance: the action or fact of meeting rules or standards
compliant: inclined to agree with others, especially submissively
comprehensive: complete, including all or nearly all elements or aspects
comprise: to consist of, being made up of
compulsion: the action or state of being forced to do something
computation: the use of computers, esp. as a subject of research or study
concession: a thing that is granted, esp. in response to demands
conciliatory: intended or likely to placate or pacify
concord: agreement or harmony between people or groups
condemn: to sentence (someone) to a particular punishment
condescension: behaviour that is patronizing or condescending
condolence: an expression of sympathy, esp. on the occasion of death
condone: accept and allow (morally wrong or offensive behavior)
confiscate: to take or seize (someone's property) with authority
conformity: similarity in form or character, agreement
conjunction: the formation of a link or connection between things
consonance: agreement or compatibility between opinion or actions
conspire: to plot something unlawful or harmful
consummate: to bring to a state of perfectio, fulfill
contemporaneous: existing or occurring in the same period of time
contentment: a state of happiness and satisfaction
context: the circumstances that form the setting of an idea
contumacious: stubbornly or willfully disobedient to authority
contumely: insolent or insulting language or treatment
conundrum: a confusing and difficult problem or question
conventional: based on or in accordance with what is generally done
convey: to make an idea or feeling know or understandable
conviction: a belief, a judgement that someone is guilty of a crime
convoluted: extremely complex and difficult to follow (argument, often)
coronation: the ceremony of crowning a sovereign or sovereign's consort
corroborate: to confirm or give support to (a statement, etc.)
countenance: a person's face or facial expression
crass: lacking in sensitivity or due consideration
credulity: willingness to believe or trust too readily
credulous: having or showing too great a readiness to believe things
critique: to give detailed analysis and assessment of something
cryptic: having a meaning that is mysterious or obscure
culmination: the highest or climactic point of something
cultivate: to prepare and use (land) for crops or gardening
cumulative: increasing in quantity or force by successive additions
cunning: having or showing skill in achieving one's ends by deceit
curator: a keeper or custodian of a museum or other collection
cursory: hasty and therefore not thorough or detailed
cynical: believing that people are motivated by self-interest
daunt: to make (someone) feel intimidated or apprehensive
debase: to reduce in quality or value
debilitate: to make someone weak and infirm
decelerate: to reduce speed, to slow down
decimate: to kill, destroy, or remove large percentages of
decipher: to succeed in understanding or interpreting
decisive: settling an issue, producing a definite result
defuse: to reduce the danger or tension in (a difficult situation)
degenerate: having fallen below a desirable level, especially morally
delirium: an acutely disturbed state of mind that occurs in fever
demur: to raise doubts or objections or show reluctance
denouement: the final part of a play, movie, or narrative
denounce: to publicly declare to be wrong or evil
despotic: characteristic of an absolute ruler or absolute rule
destitute: without the basic necessities of life
desultory: lacking a plan, purpose, or enthusiasm
detonate: to explode or cause to explode
detumescence: the process of subsiding from a state of tension
devious: showing skillful use of underhanded tactics to achieve goals
diatribe: a forceful and bitter verbal attack
diction: the style of enunciation in speaking or singing
dilettante: a person with an amateur interest in the arts, a dabbler
din: a loud, unpleasant, and prolonged noise
disabuse: to persuade someone that an idea or belief is mistaken
disaffection: a state of dissatisfaction with or alienation from something
disconcert: to disturb the composure of, to unsettle
discourteous: showing rudeness and a lack of consideration for others
discrepancy: an inconsistency between two or more facts
disparage: to regard or represent as being of little worth
disputatious: (of a person) fond of having heated arguments
disquietude: a state of uneasiness or anxiety
dissident: a person who opposes official policy
divergence: a difference or conflict in opinions, interests, wishes, etc
divergent: tending to be different or develop in different directions
diverse: showing a great deal of variety
diversion: an instance of turning something aside from its course
divination: the practice of foretelling the future by supernatural means
doggerel: verse or words that are badly written or expressed
dogma: an official system of tenets, laid down by an authority
dolorous: feeling or expressing great sorrow or distress
drub: to hit or beat (someone) repeatedly, thrash
edify: to instruct or improve (someone) morally or intellectually
efface: to erase (a mark) from the surface
efficacy: the ability to produce a desired or intended result
effusive: expressing feelings in an unrestrained or heartfelt manner
embellish: to make something more entertaining by adding extra details
embodiment: a tangible or visible form of an idea, quality, or feeling
eminent: (a person) famous and respected within a particular sphere
emissary: a person sent on a special mission
empathy: the ability to understand and share the feelings of others
encomium: a piece of writing that praises someone or something highly
encroach: to advance gradually and in a way that causes damage
endemic: natural to or characteristic of a specific people or place
endow: to furnish, as with some talent, faculty, or quality
enigma: a puzzling or inexplicable occurrence or situation
enmity: a feeling or condition of hostility, hatred, animosity
enumerate: to mention separately as if in counting, name one by one
epigram: any witty, ingenious, or pointed saying tersely expressed
epithet: any phrase applied to a person/thing to describe a quality
epitome: a person or thing that is typical of a whole class
equipoise: an equal distribution of weight, even balance, equilibrium
equivocate: to use unclear expressions, usually in order to mislead
erudite: characterized by great knowledge, learned or scholarly
erudition: knowledge acquired by study, research, etc.,  learning
eschew: to abstain or keep away from, shun, avoid
esoteric: understood by or meant for only a select few
espionage: the act or practice of spying
etymology: the derivation of a word, word origin
euphoria: a feeling of happiness, confidence, or well-being
evanescence: to disappear gradually, vanish, fade away
evocation: an act or instance of evoking,  a calling forth
ewe: a female sheep, especially when fully mature
exalt: to raise in rank, honor, power, character, quality
exasperate: to irritate or provoke to a high degree, annoy extremely
exculpate: to clear from a charge of guilt or fault,vindicate
exegesis: critical explanation or interpretation of a text
expatriate: to banish (a person) from his or her native country
extrapolate: to infer (an unknown) from something that is known
facile: moving, acting, working, proceeding, etc , with ease
famine: extreme and general scarcity of food, as in a country
feint: a movement made in order to deceive an adversary
felicitous: well-suited for the occasion, as an action or expression
feral: existing in a natural state, not domesticated, wild
ferment: living organisms (yeasts, molds) that cause fermentation
fervent: having or showing great warmth or intensity of spirit
fervid: heated or vehement in spirit, enthusiasm, etc
filial: of, pertaining to, or befitting a son or daughter
finite: having bounds or limits, not infinite, measurable
fissure: narrow opening produced by cleavage  or separation of parts
flippant: frivolously disrespectful, shallow or lacking in seriousness
flout: to treat with disdain, scorn, or contempt, scoff at, mock
foment: to instigate or foster (discord, rebellion, etc )
forage: to wander or go in search of provisions
forbid: to command not to do something, have something, etc
forensics: the use of science to answer questions for the legal system
forge: to form by heating and hammering, beat into shape
forlorn: desolate or dreary, as in feeling, condition
forthright: going straight to the point, frank, direct
fortify: to protect or strengthen against attack
fracas: a noisy, disorderly disturbance or fight
frieze: a decorative band beneath the cornice of an interior wall
fulminate: to explode with a loud noise, detonate
fulsome: offensive to good taste, especially as being excessive
fungible: being of such nature or kind as to be freely exchangeable
futile: incapable of producing any result, ineffective, useless
galvanize: to stimulate by or as if by a galvanic (electric) current
gambol: to skip about, as in dancing or playing, frolic
germinate: to begin to grow or develop
glib: readily fluent, often thoughtlessly or insincerely so
goad: to prick or drive with, or as if with, a goad, prod
gossamer: a fine, filmy cobweb seen on grass or floating in the air
gouge: to scoop out or turn with or as if with a gouge
gregarious: fond of the company of others, sociable
grouse: any gallinaceous birds of the subfamily tetraoninae
grovel: to humble oneself or act in an abject manner
guile: insidious cunning in attaining a goal, artful deception
hackles: the erectile hair on the back of an animal's neck
harbinger: a person who makes known the approach of another, herald
hence: as an inference from this fact, for this reason, therefore
herbaceous: of, pertaining to, or characteristic of an herb
hermetic: made airtight by fusion or sealing
heroine: a woman of distinguished courage or ability
hew: to strike forcibly with a cutting instrument, chop
hierarchy: any system of persons or things ranked one above another
hindsight: recognition of the realities of a situation after it happens
hue: a gradation or variety of a color, tint
hummock: an elevated tract of land above the level of a marshy region
humus: the dark organic material in soils
hybrid: the offspring of two animals or plants of different breeds
hypocrisy: pretense of having principles that one does not really have
hypothesis: a proposition given as explanation for a group of phenomena
idealist: a person who cherishes or pursues noble principles, etc
idiosyncrasy: a characteristic, habit, mannerism peculiar to an individual
immaculate: free from spot or stain, immaculately clean
impalpable: incapable of being perceived by touch, intangible
impart: to make known, to tell, to relate
impenitent: not feeling regret over one's sins
imperturbable: incapable of being upset or agitated, not easily excited
impervious: not permitting penetration or passage, impenetrable
impious: not pious or religious, lacking reverence for god, etc
implacable: not to be appeased, mollified, or pacified
implicate: to show to be involved, usually in an incriminating manner
imposture: the action or practice of imposing fraudulently upon others
improvise: to compose and perform without previous preparation
impugn: to challenge as false,cast doubt upon
impugned: dispute the validit  or honesty of a statement or motive
incantation: the uttering of words purporting to have magical power
incise: to cut into, cut marks, figures, etc
incongruous: out of keeping or place, inappropriate, unbecoming
incorrigible: not corrigible, bad beyond correction or reform
inculcate: to implant by repeated statement, teach persistently
incursion: a hostile entrance into or invasion of a place, a raid
indelible: making marks that cannot be erased, removed, or the like
indemnify: to compensate for damage or loss sustained, expense, etc
indigent: lacking food, clothing, etc because of poverty
indignity: an injury to a person's dignity
indiscernible: not discernible, that cannot be seen or perceived clearly
indiscriminate: not discriminating, lacking in care, judgment, etc
indomitable: that cannot be subdued or overcome, as persons or courage
ineffable: incapable of being expressed or described in words
inefficacious: not able to produce the desired effect, ineffective
infallible: unfailing in effectiveness or operation, certain
ingratiate: to establish (oneself) in the favor or good graces of others
innate: existing in one from birth, inborn, native
insipid: without distinctive, interesting, or stimulating qualities
insouciant: free from concern, worry, or anxiety, carefree, nonchalant
intelligible: capable of being understood, comprehensible, clear
internecine: of or pertaining to conflict or struggle within a group
interpolate: to introduce (something additional) between other things
intractable: not easily controlled, not docile or manageable, stubborn
inured: to accustom to hardship, difficulty, pain, etc
inveigh: to protest strongly or attack vehemently with words
irascible: easily provoked to anger, very irritable
jettison: to cast (goods) overboard in order to lighten a vessel
jocose: given to or characterized by joking, jesting, humorous
jocular: characterized by, or intended for joking or jesting
jubilant: showing great joy, satisfaction, or triumph, rejoicing
juggernaut: any large, overpowering, destructive force or object
jurisprudence: the science or philosophy of law
juxtapose: to place close together or side by side, esp. for comparison
kernel: the body of a seed inside the husk
knoll: a small, rounded hill or eminence, hillock
lachrymose: suggestive of or tending to cause tears, mournful
lament: to feel or express sorrow or regret for
languid: lacking in vigor or vitality, slack or slow
lassitude: weariness of body or mind from strain, oppressive climate
latent: present but not visible, apparent, or actualized, potential
laxity: the state or quality of being lax
legion: a division of the roman army of 3000 to 6000 soldiers
limerick: a kind of humorous verse of five lines
limpid: clear, transparent, or pellucid, as water, crystal, or air
lionize: to treat (a person) as a celebrity
listless: having or showing little or no interest in anything, languid
literati: persons of scholarly or literary attainments, intellectuals
liturgy: a form of public worship, ritual
loquacious: talking or tending to talk much or freely, talkative
lucid: easily understood, completely intelligible or comprehensible
lugubrious: mournful, dismal or gloomy, especially in an affected manner
magnanimous: generous in forgiving an insult or injury
malfeasance: an act by a public official that is contrary to law
malignant: disposed to cause harm, suffering, or distress deliberately
malinger: to pretend illness, especially in order to shirk one's duty
malleable: capable of being extended or shaped by hammering or pressure
maraud: to roam or go around in quest of plunder
martinet: a strict disciplinarian, especially a military one
meager: deficient in quantity or quality, lacking fullness
medieval: in the style of the middle ages
megalomania: a symptom of mental illness marked by delusions of greatness
melee: a confused hand-to-hand fight among several people
menace: something that threatens to cause evil or harm, a threat
mercenary: working or acting merely for money or other reward
meretricious: alluring by a show of flashy or vulgar attractions
merriment: cheerful or joyful gaiety, mirth, hilarity, laughter
metamorphose: to change the form or nature of, transform
metaphor: figure of speech: something used to represent something else
methodology: a sat of principles for regulating a given discipline
meticulous: showing extreme care about minute details, precise
miasma: noxious exhalations from putrescent organic matter
miser: a person who lives in poor conditions in order to save money
mitigate: to lessen in force or intensity, moderate
mnemonic: assisting or intended to assist the memory
mollify: to soften in feeling or temper, as a person, pacify, appease
monarch: a hereditary sovereign, as a king, queen, or emperor
mordant: sharply caustic or sarcastic, as wit or a speaker, biting
moribund: in a dying state, near death
morose: gloomily or sullenly ill-humored, as a person or mood
myriad: a very great or indefinite number of persons or things
necromancy: a method of divination through communication with the dead
negate: to deny the existence, evidence, or truth of
nexus: a means of connection, tie, link
nib: the point of a pen, or either of its divisions
nostalgia: a wistful desire to return to a former time in one's life
nostrum: a medicine sold with false claims and no demonstrable value
novice: a person who is new to the circumstances, work, etc
nuance: a subtle difference or distinction in expression
nugatory: of no real value, trifling, worthless
obliterate: to remove or destroy all traces of, do away with
obloquy: censure, blame, or abusive language aimed at something
obsequious: showing servile complaisance or deference, fawning
obsolete: no longer in general use, fallen into disuse
obstinate: firmly or stubbornly adhering to one's purpose, opinion
obtuse: not quick or alert in perception, not sensitive or observant
obviate: to anticipate and prevent or eliminate by effective measures
occlude: to close, shut, or stop up (a passage, opening, etc )
occult: any system claiming use or knowledge of secret forces
odious: deserving or causing hatred, hateful, detestable
odium: intense hatred, especially toward a contemptible person
omnipotent: almighty or infinite in power, as god
opprobrium: the reproach incurred by conduct considered shameful
orthodox: the traditional doctrines of an ideology, faith or religion
oscillate: to swing back and forth, especially with a regular rhythm
ossify: to convert into or cause to harden like bone
overwrought: in a state of excessive nervousness, excitement, or anger
paean: any loud and joyous song, a song of triumph
palpable: capable of being touched, felt or handled
panegyric: a lofty oration or writing in praise of a person or thing
pantomime: the art of conveying actions by gestures without speech
paradox: seemingly contradictory statement that may be true
paragon: a model or pattern of excellence
paramount: chief in importance or impact, supreme, preeminent
parch: to make extremely, excessively, or completely dry
parlance: a way or manner of speaking, vernacular, idiom
parlay: to bet or gamble on a subsequent race, contest, etc
parody: a satirical imitation of a serious piece of literature
pathology: the study of the origin, nature and course of diseases
peccadillo: a very minor sin or offence
penitent: feeling or expressing sorrow for sin or wrongdoing
perdition: a state of final spiritual ruin
perfidy: deliberate breach of faith or trust
perfunctory: performed merely as a routine duty, hasty and superficial
peril: exposure to injury, loss or destruction
peripheral: pertaining to the outside surface or boundary of an area
perspicacious: having keen mental perception and understanding
pervade: to become spread through all parts of
philistine: a person lacking in cultural values
pillory: a wooden frame with holes for securing the head and hands
piquant: agreeably pungent or sharp in taste or flavour
pith: the soft central cylinder of tissue in a plant stem
polyglot: able to speak or write several languages
poseur: a person who attempts to impress others by assuming a manner
pragmatic: pertaining to a practical point of view
precocious: unusually advanced or mature in development
prescience: knowledge of things before they happen
preside: to occupy the place of authority or control
prig: a person who is self-righteous and narrow-minded
profuse: spending or giving freely and in large amount
proliferate: to grow or produce by multiplication of parts
prolix: extended to great, unnecessary or tedious length
propagate: to cause an organism to multiply
propriety: conformity to established standards of proper behaviour
prose: the ordinary form of spoken or written language
pundit: a learned person, expert or authority
pungent: sharply affecting the organs of taste or smell
quaff: to drink something with hearty enjoyment, especially alcohol
raconteur: a person who is skilled in relating stories and anecdotes
raffish: mildly or sometimes engagingly disreputable or nonconformist
ramify: to divide or spread out into branches or branchlike parts
rancor: bitter, rankling resentment or ill will
rapacious: given to seizing for plunder or the satisfaction of greed
rasp: to scrape or abrade with a rough instrument
reciprocate: to give or feel in return
recluse: a person who lives in seclusion or apart from society
recondite: dealing with very profound or difficult subject matter
remedial: intended to improve one's skill in a specific field
reparation: the making of amends for wrong or injury done
requiem: any musical service for the repose of the dead
reticent: disposed to be silent or not speak freely
ribald: vulgar or indecent in speech, language, etc
sacred: devoted or dedicated to a deity or religious purpose
sagacious: showing acute mental discernment and keen practical sense
sagacity: acuteness of mental discernment and soundness of judgement
salve: a medical ointment for healing or relieving wounds and sores
sanction: authoritative permission or approval for an action
sartorial: pertaining to tailors and their trade
savant: a person of profound or extensive learning
scrupulous: showing a strict regard for what one considers right
scurvy: a disease caused by a diet lacking in vitamin c
sedition: incitement of discontent or rebellion against movement
shroud: a cloth in which a corpse is wrapped for burial
sinister: threatening or portending evil, harm or trouble
slake: to allay thirst, desire, etc, by satisfying it
snide: derogatory in a nasty, insinuating manner
solace: comfort in sorrow, misfortune or trouble
soluble: capable of being dissolved or liquefied
somber: dark and dull in colour or things in respect to colour
sophistry: a superficially plausible, but false method of reasoning
soporific: causing or tending to cause sleep
specious: apparently good or right though lacking real merit
spendthrift: a person who spends money extravagantly or wastefully
sporadic: appearing or happening at irregular intervals
squalid: foul and repulsive from lack of care or cleanliness
static: characterised by a fixed or stationary position
stentorian: very loud or powerful in sound
stigma: a mark of disgrace or infamy
stint: a period of time spent doing something
subliminal: existing below the threshold of consciousness
submission: the act of yielding to the will or authority of another
substantiate: to establish by proof or competent evidence
supine: lying on the back, face or front upward
symbiosis: any interdependent relationship between two things
tedium: the quality or state of being wearisome
tempt: to entice to do something often regarded as unwise or wrong
tenacity: the quality or property of being persistent or stubborn
tenet: any principle held as true by members of a group
terrestrial: representing the earth as distinct from other planets
tortuous: full of twists, turns or bends
traduce: to slander, or to speak maliciously and falsely of
transcend: to rise above or go beyond
transgress: to violate a law, command, moral code, etc
translucent: clear enough for light to pass through but not totally clear
transmute: to change from one form into another
troubadour: one of a class of medieval lyric poets
turbid: not clear because of stirred up sediment, opaque, obscured
turmoil: a state of great commotion, confusion or disturbance
tyranny: arbitrary or unrestrained exercise of power
unequivocal: having only one possible meaning or explanation
unification: the process of unifying or uniting
untenable: incapable of being defended, as an argument, thesis, etc
uproarious: in a state of uproar, confused and noisy
usury: the practice of lending money at an exorbitant interest
vagabond: wandering from place to place without any settled home
vagrant: a person who wanders and has no permanent home or employment
vainglorious: filled with excessive pride over one's own achievements
vanguard: the foremost division or the front part of an army
vapid: lacking or having lost life, sharpness or flavour
veer: to change from one course or direction to another
venal: willing to sell one's influence,  in return for a bribe
venerable: commanding respect because of great age or dignity
venerate: to regard or treat with reverence
venial: able to be forgiven or pardoned
verbose: characterised by the use of many or too many words
verdant: covered with growing plants or moss
verisimilitude: the appearance or semblance of truth
veritable: being truly or very much so
vicarious: experienced through someone else rather than first hand
vocation: a particular occupation, business or profession, calling
volatile: tending or threatening to break out into open violence
voluble: characterised by a ready and continuous flow of words
voracious: craving or consuming large quantities of food
vouchsafe: to grant or give, as by favor, graciousness or condescension
waft: to carry lightly and smoothly through the air or over water
waggish: roguish in merriment and good humor
wane: to decrease in strength, intensity, etc
wary: watchful, being on one's guard against danger
wheedle: to influence a person by smooth, flattering words or acts
whet: to sharpen by grinding or friction
wile: a trick, artifice or stratagem meant to fool, trap or entice
winnow: to remove lighter particles from grain
witty: amusingly clever in perception and expression
xenophobia: an unreasonable fear of strangers or foreigners
yearn: to have earnest or strong desire
